Award.AwardTitle: Light-Induced Chromosomal InteracKon: A New Tool to Study Chromosome Dynamics and Its Biological Roles

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a novel method to use light to control and manipulate the 3D conformation of chromosomes. Containing the genetic materials of an organism, chromosomes play essential roles in many cellular processes. To perform these functions, chromosomes often need to interact physically. Although many interactions between chromosomes have been found, how fast such interactions can be established is not clear. The project will provide a method to probe such dynamics and understand how these dynamics are regulated. This project will engage undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary research bridging genetics, imaging, and computational biology. The principle investigator is developing an interdisciplinary biophysics course, and some of the results from this project will be incorporated into two new teaching modules in that course. This project will also allow the principle investigator to continue promoting women and minority students from multiple disciplines to pursue science.

The project will engineer bakerâ€™s yeast cells in order to recruit light-induced dimerization proteins to targeted chromosome loci and then use light to induce physical interactions between the two loci. The lab will collect quantitative measurements of the time it takes the two chromosomal loci to encounter one another and to dissociate when dimerization is reversed. Next, they will examine how the phases of the cell cycle, cell size, and DNA damage affect the encounter time. The project will also probe how such induced interactions affect genome-wide chromosome conformation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Containing the genetic materials of an organism, chromosome conformation plays essential regulatory roles in fundamental cellular processes like transcription and replication. In the past few years, we made major progress in developing novel methodologies in budding yeast to detect and manipulate chromosome conformation. We also studied natural chromosomal interactions and their function in gene regulation.

 

Publications: We published three papers supported by MCB- 2016266:

 

Du MY*, Zou F*, Yan YJ, Bai L (2022) Chemically Induced Chromosomal Interaction (CICI): A New Tool to Study Chromosome Dynamics and Its Biological Roles. Nature Communications, 13: 757.

 

Li Y, Lee J, Bai L (2024) DNA Methylation-Based High-Resolution Mapping of Long-Distance Chromosomal Interactions in Nucleosome-Depleted Regions. Nature Communications, 15(1):4358

 

Lee J, Simpson L, Li Y, Becker S, Zou F, Bai L (2024) Transcription Factor Condensates Mediate Clustering of MET Regulon and Enhancement in Gene Expression.  Elife, Accepted

 

One more manuscript supported by this grant is in preparation.

 

 

Broader impacts:

Training: Two graduate students were supported by this grant, and one more graduate student and five undergraduates received training related to this grant. All three graduate students have successfully defended their thesis. Two undergraduate students served as co-authors on the papers listed above.

 

Education: The methodology developed here have been incorporated into two courses (genetics and biophysics) that I taught over the past few years.

 

Outreach: The PI and students gave ~20 talks on related topics and many poster presentations. The plasmid and strains generated from these projects have been requested and distributed to many labs around the world. The PI has a track record of exposing research and career opportunities to underrepresented minorities through programs such as MURE (Minority Undergraduate Research Experience), SROP (Summer Research Opportunities Program), and WISER (Women in Science and Engineering Research). The PI has also organized meetings, workshops, and served as judges for minority and female undergraduate students.
